title: Machine learning-based adaptive model identification of systems: Application to a chemical process
narrative: The document develops an adaptive, physics-guided data-driven framework to identify nonlinear dynamic models using sparse regression and feature selection, and demonstrates it on a non-isothermal CSTR with an exothermic second-order reaction. The three-step procedure is: (1) offline Sparse Identification of Nonlinear Dynamics (SINDy) to select candidate functions from a large library; (2) online ordinary least-squares to re-estimate coefficients as new data arrive; and (3) stepwise feature selection to retain only statistically significant terms. The approach balances model parsimony and predictive accuracy using an error trigger. The CSTR case includes Arrhenius temperature dependence in the library and uses coupled mass and energy balances to generate training/validation data. Figure 1 on page 4 presents the flowchart of the methodology. The governing first-principles CSTR balances are given in Eqs. (12)–(13) on page 6, with simulation parameters summarized in Table 1 on page 6. Table 2 on page 6 lists the true functional coefficients used for benchmarking sparse recovery. Figures 4–7 on pages 8–11 show that the adaptive method identifies compact models with substantially lower prediction error than SINDy using the same or even much larger datasets.

title: Analysis and Optimization of a CSTR by Direct Entropy Minimization
narrative: The document formulates a thermodynamically-extended nonlinear model of a non-isothermal, jacketed CSTR performing an irreversible, exothermic, first-order reaction A → B. It couples the standard dynamic mass and energy balances with an open-system entropy balance to derive an explicit expression for the reactor’s internal entropy generation rate. Using both direct (analytical) and indirect (linear nonequilibrium) thermodynamic arguments, the paper shows how minimizing entropy generation informs optimal operating conditions; notably, the direct optimization yields the condition T^e = T at the minimum. The model uses feed flowrate, feed temperature, and a heat-transfer term Q̇ = UA(T − T_c) with coolant (jacket) temperature as inputs, and predicts reactor temperature T, outlet concentration C_A, and entropy generation rate σ̇. Table 1 on page 2 lists nominal parameters (V, F^e, C_A^e, T^e, ρ, c_p, E/R, k_0, UA, T_c, ΔH^0, ΔG^0). Figure 1 on page 2 depicts the jacketed CSTR configuration supporting these balances.
